subject: Psychology
title: ACEs and Lifelong Health
description: A short lesson to help you apply ACEs and Lifelong Health.

hook.text: A doctor noticed his sickest patients had difficult childhoods. He wondered: could childhood stress cause adult disease?

buildup.text: The ACE Study (Adverse Childhood Experiences) surveyed 17,000 adults about childhood trauma and current health.

discovery.text: Higher ACE scores predicted heart disease, diabetes, depression, addiction, and early death in a dose-response pattern.

twist.text: ACEs were shockingly common. Two-thirds of participants reported at least one. Over 12% reported four or more.

climax.text: Childhood stress rewires the developing brain. Early adversity casts a long biological shadow across the lifespan.

punchline.text: Childhood stress doesn't stay in childhood. It echoes through decades.

quiz.question: What did the ACE Study find about childhood adversity?
options: Higher ACE scores predicted worse adult health outcomes
Childhood experiences have no lasting health effects
Only physical abuse affects long-term health
